To firmly engage bracket 1101 into groove 114, bracket 1101 may further include another hook-shaped flange, or tab, such as upper hook 1105, which may be attached to bracket 1101 as by or via a spring member, flange, or arm, such as spring arm 1104. Spring arm 1104 may be adapted such that spring arm 1104 may be deflected towards PV module 102 such that upper hook 1105 may be forced down and into groove 114. When spring arm 1104 is released, upper hook 1105 may engage key slot 130a and bearing surface 124, thereby securely attaching wind diffuser 1100 to PV module 102. Bracket 1101 may also include a surface, or protrusion, such as pushing surface 1106 for convenient placement of one's thumb, hand or tool, with which to exert force upon spring arm 1104. The instant embodiment may provide advantages over prior art wind diffusers and deflectors due to the simple, low cost, snap-in connection method to a PV module frame.
[366] Additional embodiments of a tilt interlock (see, for example those shown in Figs. 37-38) are shown in Figs. 112-117. In Fig. 112 there is shown a structural system comprising a tilt interlock such as tilt interlock 1120 that may interlock together two, three, or four PV modules 102 by connecting PV modules 102 to tilt interlock 1120 via couplings and tongues as will be discussed in more detail below.

[367] Tilt interlock 1120 may be constructed of sheet steel, extruded aluminum, plastic, concrete, or any suitably stiff material. Tilt interlock 1120 is similar to several previously described structural systems except that it is composed of fewer components, namely a supporting body, such as body 1121. In some embodiments body 1121 comprises a coupling, such as coupling 1122, similar to accessory coupling 198, as shown in Figure 27, for attaching body 1121 to a PV module frame, such as frame 1 12 in PV module 102. Body 1121 may further include integral features adapted to engage the frame of a PV module. Thus, in some

embodiments body 1121 may function as an interlock for coupling together 2, 3, or 4 PV modules 102. Figure 112 illustrates body 1121 with a feature for engaging a groove in a PV module frame, such as groove 114, as by a flange, tab, or pivot-fitting tongue, such as tongue

1123. It is specifically contemplated that coupling 1122 and tongue 1123 may be substituted by alternative coupling means, and body 1121 may be adapted to function with said alternative coupling means. For example, tongue 1123 may be replaced by an engaging feature similar to engaging portion 821 as shown in Figure 82, or a wrap-around structural system, similar to wrap- around engaging portion 831 as shown in Figure 83. Also for example, coupling 1122 may be replaced with, and body 1121 adapted for, a pivoting lock arm, such as spring bracket 1161 as shown in Figures 116 and 117, similar to spring bracket 1013 as shown in Figure 101. Note that spring bracket 1161 is shown here in a view so that lower portion 1170 may be seen applying
force to an underside of flange 1171 on body 1121 when in its final installed position.

[368] One skilled in the art will recognize that body 1121 may be further adapted as a hollow body, extrusion, or rail which may have a channel formed therein, such as rail 1150 in Figure 115 and rail 1160 in Figure 116, or with clips, flanges, or tabs, which may provide a means to attach ballast stones or blocks, such as, for example, ballast blocks 751 as shown in Figure 75.

[369] Figures 118-119 show a further embodiment of a structural system, such as structural system 1180, for supporting tilted PV modules. Structural system 1180 may be constructed of sheet steel, extruded aluminum, or any suitably stiff material. Structural system 1180 is similar to several previously described structural systems, such as structural system 112 in Figure 112, except that it may be composed of a main body 1190 adapted to receive coupling members, structures, arms, legs, or the like, such as lower leg 1191 and upper leg 1192. Lower leg 1191 and upper leg 1192 may be attached to main body 1190 as by screws, rivets, clips, welds, or the like, or as shown by means of keyed male and female features, such as slot 1193 and tongue 1194. Upper leg 1192 may be adapted to connect to a PV module as by couplings, clips, flanges, or the like, such as coupling 1195, similar to accessory coupling 198, as shown in Figure 27.

Lower leg 1191 may be adapted to connect to a PV module as by couplings, clips, flanges, or the like, such as by tongue 1196, similar to tongue 1123 in Figure 112. It is recognized that upper leg 1192 and lower leg 1192 may be interchangeable with alternative lower legs and upper legs that may provide different heights or lengths so as to change the tilt angle or position of the PV module.

[370] Figures 120-128 show a further embodiment of a structural system, such as tilt interlock 1200, for supporting tilted PV modules. Tilt interlock 1200 may be constructed of sheet steel, extruded aluminum, plastic, or any suitably stiff material. Tilt interlock 1200 is similar to
several previously described structural systems, such as tilt interlock 1120 in Figure 112, except that body 1121 is replaced by body 1201 which may be lower profile and may have other notable features as will be described below. For example, body 1201 may comprise a spring clip or similar snap-in or latching type securing device, such as drop-in clip 1220, instead of coupling 1122. In some embodiments body 1201 may comprise one or two drop-in clips 1220, typically body 1201 comprises from 1 to 6 drop-in clips 1220, with additional clips being utilized for added strength. Drop-in clips 1220 may also connect to a feature running substantially the length of body 1201 thereby allowing drop-in clips to be connected to PV module 102 at positions both near the 4-corners junction of 4 PV modules 102 and away from this region. Such a feature may enable greater flexibility in mounting since tilt interlock 1200 may be easily connected to PV module 102 at various positions along a length of frame 112. It may also be possible to install tilt interlocks 1200 at the 4-corners junction plus additional tilt interlocks in between such regions, thereby increasing the overall strength and/or stiffness of the structural system. For example, additional tilt interlocks 1200 may be installed in between tilt interlocks 1200 as shown in Fig 120. Body 1201 of the instant embodiment may also comprise a pivot- fit mechanism such as pivot- fit retainer 1226.

[371] Body 1201, as shown in Fig. 122, may comprise a portion adapted to interlock PV modules 102 together along a front or lower edge, such as front interlock portion 1221, and a portion adapted to interlock PV modules 102 together along a rear or upper edge, such as rear interlock portion 1222. Front and rear interlock portions 1221, 1222 may be used for either interlocking PV modules 102 within a row, or may connect an end-of-row module 102 to body 1201 and thus to the next end-of-row module in an adjacent row (as shown in Fig. 120). As may be more evident when viewing Fig. 120, a height difference between front interlock portion 1221
and rear interlock portion 1222 may result in modules 102 being tilted with respect to a plane of a roof or support structure (not shown), thereby enabling the creation of tilted rows of PV modules 102 forming an overall PV array 1202. Fig. 121 provides a side view which reveals an approximate tilt angle of 5 degrees relative to horizontal for each row of PV modules 102 in PV array 1202. Typically, rows may be tilted between 3-30 degrees by varying the height difference between front interlock portion 1221 and rear interlock portion 1222 and/or a width of PV modules 102. A width of body 1201 may be optimized to minimize power loss resulting from row-to-row shading effects. For example, the instant embodiment contemplates a distance to height ratio of 2.5 to 1 when comparing the horizontal distance (dashed line D in Fig. 121) between a top surface of PV modules 102 in two adjacent rows to the vertical height (dashed line H in Fig. 121) between said top surfaces. Other embodiments contemplate distance to height ratios in the range of 1 to 1 up to 10 to 1. Figure 121 indicates with broken lines that body 1201 may be shortened or lengthened, thereby decreasing or increasing the height to distance ratio. Body 1201 may further comprise a generally horizontal portion or surface, such as body top surface 1223, which may provide a walkable surface that allows an installer to easily step on body 1201 instead of having to step over body 1201 when walking between rows of PV modules 102 in PV array 1202. Body 1201 may also comprise generally flat downward facing portions adapted to rest on or connect to a roof surface, such as front base portion 1224 and rear base portion 1225. In some embodiments front base portion 1224 and rear base portion 1225 may comprise rubber or other softer material to prevent body 1201 from damaging a roof. As shown in Fig. 122, front base portion 1224 and rear base portion 1225 may comprise flanges projecting toward each other and generally underneath body 1201 to hold ballast blocks 751 or similar ballasting material should such ballast be necessary to resist local wind uplift loads. In some
- I l l - embodiments adjacent bodies 1201 are joined by a wind diffuser similar to wind diffuser 980 in Fig. 98 or wind diffuser 1000 in Fig. 100. In other embodiments as will be discussed below with respect to Fig. 128, body 1201 may also function as a wind diffuser. In some embodiments front base portion 1224 and rear base portion 1225 may further comprise a screw, bolt, hold-down, or standoff for positively securing body 1201 to a roof or support structure. In still further embodiments a shape of body 1201 may be optimized ia calculations and/or wind tunnel modeling to minimize or eliminate the need for ballast vand/or positive connections to a roof.

[372] Referring to Figs. 122-123, drop-in clip 1220 may be constructed from bent spring steel, plastic, or other substantially stiff material that is resilient in the direction of spring travel (see below). As an example, drop-in clip 1220 as shown in Fig. 123 may comprise a lower spring or resilient portion for engagement with an underside of PV module 102, such as lower spring 1232, and an upper spring for snapping into engagement with groove 114 in PV module 102, such as upper spring 1233. Drop-in clip 1220 may further comprise an engaging portion for at least partial capture by a portion of body 1201, such as engaging portion 1230, and a stiffening flange for providing stiffness in a direction opposing a facing surface of PV module 102 (see below), such as stiffening flange 1231. In some embodiments engaging portion 1230 may be loosely connected (for easy field positioning) to body 1201 by sliding into clip connecting portion 1227, whereas in other embodiments engaging portion may be fastened to body 1201 or press-fit or swaged into clip connecting portion 1227. Lower spring 1232 may comprise a grounding portion, such as grounding tab 1234, adapted to deform a portion of PV module frame 112 in order to create a ground bond between drop-in clip 1220 and PV module frame 112.

[373] In some embodiments drop-in clip 1220 is of one-piece construction and in other embodiments drop-in clip 1220 comprises multiple pieces. For example, drop-in clip 1220 as
shown in Fig. 123 comprises a first piece and a second piece, wherein the first piece comprises upper spring 1233 and lower spring 1232 and the second piece comprises body 1239. As shown in Fig. 123, upper spring 1233 may comprise a horizontal or slightly downward angled tab, flange, or portion, such as retaining portion 1235, the function of which will be described in more detail below. As described in more detail below, drop-in clip 1220 may provide enable a simple an rapid method of connecting PV modules 102 to rear interlock portion 1222, thereby enabling fast mounting and coupling of adjacent PV modules 102.

[374] Additional portions of tilt interlock 1200 are shown in Figs. 124-125, specifically portions of tilt interlock 1200 that enable connection of PV module 102 to the front, or lower, side of body 1201. Pivot- fit retainer 1226, as shown in perspective in Fig. 124, may be manufactured from stamped, bent, extruded or formed metal or plastic or other suitable material and may be connected to body 1201 in any of the ways mentioned above for connection of drop- in clip 1220 to body 1201. One or more (typically from 1 to 6) pivot-fit retainers 1226 together with the front portion of body 1201 form front interlock portion 1221, which may enable rapid pivot- fit coupling of adjacent PV modules in PV array 1202. Pivot-fit retainer 1226 may comprise a generally horizontal portion for wrapping around frame 112 or engaging groove 114, such as frame engaging portion 1240. In some embodiments, such as the instant embodiment, frame engaging portion 1240 may further comprise a catch 1241 for resisting horizontal disengagement with frame 112. Pivot- fit retainer may further comprise a mechanism or fastener for connecting to body 1201, such as body engaging portion 1242. In some embodiments body engaging portion may further comprise deforming edge 1243 which may help to secure and/or provide a reliable ground between pivot- fit retainer 1226 and body 1201. As shown in Fig. 25, pivot- fit retainer is connected to body 1201. PV module 102 may then be connected to interlock
portion 1221 via a pivot-fit action whereby PV module 102 is first held at an insertion angle, moved in the direction marked A, and then rotated in the direction marked B. As seen in the final and connected position of PV module 102 (shown in dashed lines in Fig. 25), offset bearing surface 128 and lower bearing surface 1250 are offset horizontally to enable a reliable connection between frame 112 and interlock 1221 similar to other pivot-fit connections described above.

[375] Figs. 126-127 show the connecting action of rear interlock portion 1222 as PV module 102 is inserted and rotated downward as shown in Fig. 125. With PV module 102 held in the position shown in Fig. 126, body 1201 is moved toward PV module 102 in the direction A. Once drop-in clip body 1236 contacts frame 112 (as indicated by the dashed line rendering in Fig. 126), PV module 102 is dropped downward in the direction of B. One skilled in the art will recognize that downward motion of frame 112 pushes upper spring 1233 to the left then begins pushing lower spring 1232 downward. As the downward motion continues, upper spring may slide along lower face of frame 112 until reaching the opening of groove 114, at which time upper spring 1233 snaps to the right and engages lower surface 126 (see Fig. 4). In the final connected position shown in Fig. 127, lower spring 1232 may be exerting an upward force on frame 112 and upper spring may be exerting a force to the right, thereby effectively connecting PV module 102 to rear interlock portion 1222. Since the highest loads in PV array 1202 are typically vertical (up and down), upper spring 1233 (with its left-right direction of throw) may resist upward vertical loads along its strongest axis and lower spring 1232 may be substantially prevented from resisting downward vertical loads since frame 112 may contact body portion as shown in Fig. 127.

[376] Fig. 128 shows a top view of a PV array such as PV array 1282 comprising bodies 1281.
PV array 1282 is similar to PV array 1202 except that bodies 1281 are longer than bodies 1201 and comprise a length approximately equal to 0.75 times a length of PV module 102. This embodiment contemplates a body 1281 length from 0.5 to 1 times the length of PV module 102, with the exact length being calculated to minimize uplift due to the wind. In the instant embodiment the length of body 1281 allows tight packing of bodies at the end of a row (right side of Fig. 128) and more spacing between bodies in non-perimeter locations. This arrangement provides advantages in common conditions such as higher wind pressures near the perimeter and lower wind pressures in the interior of PV array 1282. Bodies 1281 may also comprise a length that allows for near or complete elimination of body 1281 material protruding outward from the end of a row of PV modules 102 in PV array 1282. This feature enables better PV module 102 density on a roof when compared to many prior art systems.

[377] Figs. 129-131 show an alternate embodiment of a structural system with similar features to the embodiments described in Figs 120-128 except that instead of a tilt interlock which may connect PV modules 102 within rows and between rows, the instant embodiment contemplates a structural system optimized for creating independent rows 1300 of PV modules 102. As shown in Fig. 129, structural system 1290 may comprise a rail, beam, or pan-like element for spanning a substantially horizontal distance beneath a PV module 102, such as base 1291. Base 1291 may be connected via fasteners, rivets, press-fit, or the like to front interlock portion 1293 and rear interlock portion 1294, which may be similar to front and rear interlock portions 1221, 1222 respectively, as described above. In some embodiments front and rear interlock portions 1293, 1294 may be rotatably connected to base so that each may be rotated flat for easier packaging and shipping. Front and rear interlock portions 1293, 1294 may comprise pivot- fit retainers 1295 and drop-in clips 1296, each of which may be similar to like devices described in previous
embodiments. Base 1291 may further comprise ballast blocks 1297. An advantage of the instant embodiment may be that multiple mechanically independent rows may be constructed on a roof with numerous obstructions located between rows, such as electrical equipment, grounding equipment, lightning protection equipment, mechanical equipment, and the like.

[378] Figs. 132-133 show an alternate embodiment of a tilt foot as discussed in previous embodiments, such as tilt foot 650, tilt foot 770, tilt foot 800, tilt foot 810, tilt foot 820, and tilt foot 830. Tilt foot 1320 operates in a similar manner to many of the previously described tilt feet, except that tilt foot 1320 may engage a rail such as rail 1321 in a substantially external manner, as opposed to inside a channel, such as channel 697 as previously discussed. Deforming edges 676, as previously discussed, a replaced by deforming edges 1322 which deform or cut an outside surface of rail 1321 when tilt foot 1320 is rocked into engagement with rail 1321. Spring clip 671 is replaced here by a fastener, pin, or press-fit device, such as threaded fastener 1323 or pin 1324. To connect tilt foot 1320 to rail 1321, tilt foot 1320 may be tilted at an angle slid around rail 1321, rotated clockwise, then connected to rail via pin 1324. Tilt foot may further comprise interlock portion 1325 which may operate in a similar manner to interlock 651.

[379] Figs. 134-135 show an alternate embodiment of a tilt interlock, which may be similar to tilt interlock 1200 except drop-in clips 1220 may be replaced by one or multiple spring brackets, such as spring brackets 1340, 1341, in order to connect a tilt interlock, such as tilt interlock 1342, to one or two PV modules 102. Spring brackets 1340, 1341 may differ from spring bracket 1161, as discussed previously, in that they are handed (spring bracket 1341 rotates clockwise and spring bracket 1340 rotates counterclockwise) and a single spring bracket, such as spring bracket 1340, connects only one PV module 102 to tilt interlock. Fig. 134 shows an end-of-row condition, but one of skill in the art will recognize that utilizing tilt interlock in place of the
centermost tilt interlock 1200 in Fig. 120 will result in spring bracket 1341 coupling a first PV module 102 to interlock 1342 and spring bracket 1340 coupling a second PV module 102 to tilt interlock 1342, thereby resulting in a coupling of said first and second PV modules 102. Spring brackets 1340, 1341 may comprise a generally C-shaped portion 1343 which is positionable with an upper horizontal portion at least partially in groove 114 (or on top of frame 112 in other embodiments) and a lower horizontal portion beneath a flange 1344 on tilt interlock when held at a first angle (indicated by the solid line renderings of spring brackets 1340, 1341). Rotation of each spring bracket 1340, 1341 to the position indicated by dashed lines causes C-shaped portions to exert downward force on bearing surface 128 and upward force on flange 1344, thereby connecting PV module 102 to tilt interlock. Tab 1345 functions substantially the same as tab 1053 as previously described. In other embodiments, spring brackets 1340, 1341 replace C- shaped portions 1343 with I-shaped portions and double tabs and are thus reversible and not handed.

[380] Figs. 136-138 show another alternate embodiment of a tilt interlock, which may be similar to tilt interlock 1200 except drop-in clips 1220 may be replaced by one or multiple pivot- fit brackets, such as pivot-fit bracket 1360, in order to connect a tilt interlock, such as tilt interlock 1342, to one or two PV modules 102. Pivot- fit bracket may comprise a tongue portion 1363, which operates in a similar manner to previously described pivot-fit tongue portions to connect pivot-fit bracket 1360, and thus tilt interlock 1362 to groove 114. Fig. 138 shows the insertion position and final position for tilt interlock 162 as it is connected to PV module 102 or a pair of adjacent PV modules 102. Pivot- fit bracket 1360 may be connected to tilt interlock 1362 via a removable fastener 1361 thereby enabling removal of a single PV module 102 from within the middle of an array of PV modules 102 by loosening fastener 1361, reversing pivot- fit bracket
back out, then reversing the drop-in sequence for PV module 102 as previously described. This embodiment may simplify installation.

[381] Figs. 139 and 140 show another alternate embodiment of a tilt interlock, which may be similar to tilt interlock 1200 except drop-in clips 1220 may be replaced by one or slide-on brackets, such as slide-on bracket 1390, in order to connect a tilt interlock, such as tilt interlock 1392, to one or two PV modules 102. Slide-on brackets connect a flange on tilt interlock 1392 to a frame 112 by sliding into position as shown by the arrows in Fig. 139. Slide-on bracket 1390 may comprise sharp edges, such as edges 1393, 1394 for deforming the materials and creating a ground bond and it may also wrap around bearing surface 128 and flange 1395 or it may wrap around a top of frame 112 and flange 1395. This embodiment may provide a reduction in materials and costs.

[382] While a number of exemplary aspects and embodiments have been discussed above, those of skill in the art will recognize certain modifications, permutations, additions and subcombinations thereof. It is therefore intended that the following appended claims and claims hereafter introduced be interpreted to include all such modifications, permutations, additions, and sub-combinations as are within their true spirit and scope.

claims.claim-statement: CLAIMS What is claimed as invention is:

claim.claim-text: 1. A bracket for mounting a photovoltaic module comprising:
a coupling portion adapted to connect said bracket to a PV module; and
a pivoting mechanism adapted to connect said bracket to a structural system.

2. The bracket of Claim 1 wherein said pivoting mechanism comprises a pivot portion and an engaging portion, said engaging portion being adapted to rotate substantially about said pivot portion and to engage at least a portion of said structural system.
3. The bracket of Claim 1 wherein said structural system comprises a rail and said bracket connects to said rail.

4. The bracket of Claim 1 wherein said pivoting mechanism further comprises a connecting arm, said connecting arm extending outward from said pivot portion and connecting said bracket to said structural system.
5. The bracket of Claim 1 wherein said connecting arm comprises a spring clip.
6. A bracket for mounting a photovoltaic module wherein:
said bracket is positionable essentially along a length of a portion of a structural system at a first angle and connects to said structural system at a second angle less than said first angle.

7. The bracket of Claim 6 further comprising an arm and an engaging portion, said arm being operable to rock said bracket and to cause said engaging portion to deform at least a portion of a structural system.
8. The bracket of Claim 6 wherein said bracket is positionable essentially anywhere along said length of said portion of said structural system.
9. The bracket of Claim 6 wherein said structural system essentially comprises a rail.
10. The bracket of Claim 6, wherein at least a portion of said bracket deforms at least a portion of said structural system when said bracket is connected to said structural system.
11. A bracket for mounting a photovoltaic module comprising:
a lever arm and an engaging portion, said lever arm being operable to engage said engaging portion with at least a portion of a structural system.
12. The bracket of Claim 11 wherein said bracket rocks.
13. The bracket of Claim 11 wherein said lever arm is adapted for connecting to at least a portion of said structural system.
14. The bracket of claim 13 wherein said lever arm comprises a spring clip.

15. The bracket of Claim 11 wherein said bracket further comprises a rocking portion, said lever arm protruding in a first direction away from said rocking portion and said engaging portion protruding in a second direction away from said rocking portion.
16. The bracket of Claim 11 wherein said structural system comprises a ballast portion.
17. The bracket of Claim 11 wherein at least a portion of said structural system comprises essentially a rail.

18. The bracket of Claim 11 further comprising a coupling and a rocking portion, said coupling comprising a second portion extending in a direction away from said rocking portion for connecting to said photovoltaic module and an adjacent photovoltaic module.
19. The bracket of Claim 12 wherein said bracket deforms at least a portion of said structural system when said bracket is rocked.
20. The bracket of Claim 19 wherein said deformation provides a ground bond between said bracket and said structural system.
